docs.lead_paragraph: Until now, evidence that the Mediterranean diet reduced the risk of heart disease was weak, and some experts had been skeptical that the effect of diet could be detected.

headline.main: Mediterranean Diet Shown to Ward Off Heart Attack and Stroke
headline.print_headline: Mediterranean Diet Shown to Ward Off Heart Attack and Stroke

docs.abstract: Study published in The New England Journal of Medicine finds that people age 55 to 80 who eat a Mediterranean diet of vegetables, fruits and fish, supplemented with nuts and olive oil, are at lower risk of heart attacks, strokes and death from heart disease than people on typical low-fat diet; experts say large and rigorous study, which offers conclusive evidence of benefits, is a triumph because it shows a diet is powerful in reducing heart disease risk.
docs.snippet: Until now, evidence that the Mediterranean diet reduced the risk of heart disease was weak, and some experts had been skeptical that the effect of diet could be detected.

docs.lead_paragraph: Did the battle to fight AIDS ultimately kill Spencer Cox, one of its early warriors? Mr. Cox appears in the documentary “How to Survive a Plague,” which has been nominated for an Academy Award.

headline.seo: What Really Killed Spencer Cox, AIDS activist?
headline.main: Surviving AIDS, but Not the Life That Followed

docs.abstract: Death of veteran AIDS activist Spencer Cox, who appears in Oscar-nominated documentary How to Survive a Plague, puzzles friends and fellow activists and generates a furious debate over just what his death represents; Cox, who had devoted his life to obtaining lifesaving medications for AIDS patients around the world, suddenly stopped taking his own medications.
docs.snippet: Did the battle to fight AIDS ultimately kill Spencer Cox, one of its early warriors? Mr. Cox appears in the documentary “How to Survive a Plague,” which has been nominated for an Academy Award.
